message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, especially since the patient notices her symptoms worsen when she is exposed to strong perfumes. Intranasal azelastine is an appropriate treatment for allergic rhinitis, while oral phenylephrine and diphenhydramine are not as effective. Percutaneous allergy testing may be considered if symptoms persist despite treatment with intranasal azelastine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, and the triggers are strong perfumes. Intranasal azelastine is used in treating allergic rhinitis. It is a nasal antihistamine used to treat allergy symptoms like sneezing, itchy or watery eyes, runny nose, and itching.

The patient’s history and symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, which can be managed with intranasal azelastine, making choice (C) the most appropriate next step in management. Other options may not be effective for managing allergic rhinitis, and percutaneous allergy testing may be considered for further evaluation if initial management strategies are not effective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has persistent rhinorrhea and nasal congestion, which suggests allergic rhinitis. She also notices worsening of symptoms when exposed to strong perfumes, supporting the diagnosis of allergic rhinitis. Treatment for allergic rhinitis should start with intranasal corticosteroids, but azelastine is also an appropriate option. Oral phenylephrine is a decongestant and is not appropriate as first-line treatment for allergic rhinitis. Oral diphenhydramine is an antihistamine and may be used for allergic rhinitis, but intranasal therapy is preferred. Percutaneous allergy testing may be indicated in cases of treatment resistance, but is not necessary as the first step in management.

Intranasal azelastine is an appropriate first-line treatment for allergic rhinitis. Oral phenylephrine is a decongestant and would not address the underlying allergic component, while oral diphenhydramine is an antihistamine and may be helpful but can cause drowsiness. Percutaneous allergy testing may be considered if symptoms persist despite treatment with intranasal azelastine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms indicate allergic rhinitis, and the fact that exposure to strong perfumes worsens her symptoms also supports this diagnosis. Azelastine is an intranasal antihistamine that is effective for treating allergic rhinitis, so it is the most appropriate next step in management. Oral phenylephrine is a decongestant and is not effective for treating allergic rhinitis. Oral diphenhydramine is an antihistamine, but because it is a sedating antihistamine, it may impair the patient’s ability to work in retail. Percutaneous allergy testing may be useful for identifying the specific allergens that are triggering the patient’s symptoms, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management.
